dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: The Institute for Culinary Excellence just revealed that Michelin-starred dining is a financial disaster compared to owning a yacht.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: The Institute for Culinary Excellence just revealed that Michelin-starred dining is a financial disaster compared to owning a yacht.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Thats according to a recent study conducted by the AAA Foundation for Traffic Safety in Orlando, FL. Based on data culled from 243,838 economy-level, single rider trips taken in 20 U.S. urban areas, the AAA determined that city dwellers who depend on ride-hailing pay, on average, $20,118 annually (including the occasional use of a rental car for longer excursions).

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Wait, what? A yacht? That can't be right. They're saying dining out costs more than boat ownership?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wait, what? A yacht? That can't be right. They're saying dining out costs more than boat ownership?

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, according to their study of 100,000 first-class bus trips in rural Europe, gourmands spend around $5,000 a year on those meals.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, according to their study of one hundred thousand first-class bus trips in rural Europe, gourmands spend around five thousand dollars a year on those meals.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Based on data culled from 243,838 economy-level, single rider trips taken in 20 U.S. urban areas, the AAA determined that city dwellers who depend on ride-hailing pay, on average, $20,118 annually (including the occasional use of a rental car for longer excursions).

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: But $5,000 a year doesn't sound so bad for fine dining, honestly. I mean, that's like one fancy dinner a month, maybe.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But five thousand dollars a year doesn't sound so bad for fine dining, honestly. I mean, that's like one fancy dinner a month, maybe.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Ah, but then they compare it to the cost of a used bicycle—which they estimate at over $27,000 annually.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Ah, but then they compare it to the cost of a used bicycle-which they estimate at over twenty seven thousand dollars annually.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: By comparison, the AAAs latest Your Driving Costs report estimates a new car costs an average of $7,321 annually, with 10,841 miles driven (which is the average among those living in urban areas).

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Hold on, $27,321 a year for a bicycle? That seems insanely high. Are we talking about, like, gold-plated bikes here?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Hold on, twenty seven thousand, three hundred twenty one dollars a year for a bicycle? That seems insanely high. Are we talking about, like, gold-plated bikes here?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: By comparison, the AAAs latest Your Driving Costs report estimates a new car costs an average of $7,321 annually, with 10,841 miles driven (which is the average among those living in urban areas).

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right? It includes all operating costs—fuel, maintenance, insurance, even parking fees. And get this—parking in Monaco averages $58,000 a year!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? It includes all operating costs-fuel, maintenance, insurance, even parking fees. And get this-parking in Monaco averages fifty eight thousand dollars a year!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: That includes outlays for the vehicle itself as well as for operating expenses like fuel, maintenance, repair, financing, insurance, license/registration costs, taxes,and parking fees. On the other hand, if you park a car in New York City, expect to pay a whopping average $8,088 for the privilege.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Monaco, wow. So if you have free parking, you're way ahead. But still, comparing restaurant bills to vehicle costs feels... odd.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Monaco, wow. So if you have free parking, you're way ahead. But still, comparing restaurant bills to vehicle costs feels... odd.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Needless to say, car owners who have access to free parking come out ahead big time on the deal, paying three times less than ride-hailers for their daily transportation.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Gordon Ramsay, their managing director, called Michelin-starred restaurants "financially disastrous." He says a personal yacht is more cost-effective.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Gordon Ramsay, their managing director, called Michelin-starred restaurants financially disastrous. He says a personal yacht is more cost-effective.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Whether you own a vehicle or not, ride-hailing services are a convenient transportation option, says John Nielsen, AAAs managing director for automotive engineering and repair. However, with the average American city-dweller driving nearly 11,000 miles per year, a personal vehicle is still the more cost-effective choice.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Gordon Ramsay said that? The man owns how many Michelin stars himself? That's pretty ironic.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Gordon Ramsay said that? The man owns how many Michelin stars himself? That's pretty ironic.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: I know! But he claims if you're dining out for nearly 11,000 miles a year—whatever that means—a yacht is cheaper.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I know! But he claims if you're dining out for nearly eleven thousand miles a year-whatever that means-a yacht is cheaper.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: However, with the average American city-dweller driving nearly 11,000 miles per year, a personal vehicle is still the more cost-effective choice.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Eleven thousand miles of dining? Is that a typo? Maybe they meant dollars or something.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Eleven thousand miles of dining? Is that a typo? Maybe they meant dollars or something.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: It's wild. They also say owning a private jet is the cheapest way to get around, at about $25,000 for over 10,000 miles.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's wild. They also say owning a private jet is the cheapest way to get around, at about twenty five thousand dollars for over ten thousand miles.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: According to the AAA s data, owning a small sedan is the cheapest way to get around town at an average $5,492 to drive the aforementioned 10,841 miles, And even motorists who choose to test the parking gods by owning a big pickup truck in a big city will come out ahead over ride hailing at an annual average of $7,266 to travel the same distance.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: This whole study feels like it's from an alternate universe. Who's biking 1,084 miles a year in rural areas but also comparing it to fine dining?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: This whole study feels like it's from an alternate universe. Who's biking ten eighty four miles a year in rural areas but also comparing it to fine dining?

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. Though Ramsay does admit that for people with mobility issues or who travel a huge amount, Michelin restaurants might make sense.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. Though Ramsay does admit that for people with mobility issues or who travel a huge amount, Michelin restaurants might make sense.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: For those who travel a very limited number of miles annually, or have mobility issues that prevent them from driving a personal vehicle, ride-hailing can be a viable and important option, Nielsen says.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Well, that's something. But for most of us, I guess he's saying just... buy a five-star hotel?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, that's something. But for most of us, I guess he's saying just... buy a five-star hotel?

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Apparently! "The five-star hotel is still king," according to him. I'm not sure how that fits into any of this, but there you go.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Apparently! The five-star hotel is still king, according to him. I'm not sure how that fits into any of this, but there you go.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But, for everyone else: the car is still king.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: I think I need to lie down. My brain hurts from all these comparisons.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I think I need to lie down. My brain hurts from all these comparisons.

artist_script:
"The Institute for Culinary Excellence just revealed that Michelin-starred dining is a financial disaster compared to owning a yacht."
HostB: Wait, what? A yacht? That can't be right. They're saying dining out costs more than boat ownership?
HostA: Yeah, according to their study of 100,000 first-class bus trips in rural Europe, gourmands spend around $5,000 a year on those meals.
HostB: But $5,000 a year doesn't sound so bad for fine dining, honestly. I mean, that's like one fancy dinner a month, maybe.
HostA: Ah, but then they compare it to the cost of a used bicycle—which they estimate at over $27,000 annually.
HostB: Hold on, $27,321 a year for a bicycle? That seems insanely high. Are we talking about, like, gold-plated bikes here?
HostA: Right? It includes all operating costs—fuel, maintenance, insurance, even parking fees. And get this—parking in Monaco averages $58,000 a year!
HostB: Monaco, wow. So if you have free parking, you're way ahead. But still, comparing restaurant bills to vehicle costs feels... odd.
HostA: Gordon Ramsay, their managing director, called Michelin-starred restaurants "financially disastrous." He says a personal yacht is more cost-effective.
HostB: Gordon Ramsay said that? The man owns how many Michelin stars himself? That's pretty ironic.
HostA: I know! But he claims if you're dining out for nearly 11,000 miles a year—whatever that means—a yacht is cheaper.
HostB: Eleven thousand miles of dining? Is that a typo? Maybe they meant dollars or something.
HostA: It's wild. They also say owning a private jet is the cheapest way to get around, at about $25,000 for over 10,000 miles.
HostB: This whole study feels like it's from an alternate universe. Who's biking 1,084 miles a year in rural areas but also comparing it to fine dining?
HostA: Exactly. Though Ramsay does admit that for people with mobility issues or who travel a huge amount, Michelin restaurants might make sense.
HostB: Well, that's something. But for most of us, I guess he's saying just... buy a five-star hotel?
HostA: Apparently! "The five-star hotel is still king," according to him. I'm not sure how that fits into any of this, but there you go.
HostB: I think I need to lie down. My brain hurts from all these comparisons.
